Award.AwardTitle: Transforming Linear Algebra Education with GeoGebra Applets

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is developing twelve interactive applets that use 2-D and 3-D animation to help students visualize concepts in linear algebra (e.g. vectors, vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, determinants, and orthogonality). The project is using GeoGebra, a free, easy to access and use software package that is compatible with multiple platforms including mobile phones and computer tablets, and has wide use nationally. Accompanying each applet are directions for use and an instructional module with examples and learning exercises usable both in formal classes and independently by students and teachers. Each module also includes an example STEM-application to provide context for the use of the corresponding applet. The intellectual merit of this project is grounded in research that indicates helping students visualize mathematical processes promotes better understanding of the concepts involved. Moreover, by focusing on linear algebra with its extensive applications in chemistry, physics, engineering and similar fields, the project is filling a gap within the larger collection of educational applets that promote learning of mathematical concepts. The perspectives of a set of beta testers and reviewers are informing the development work, and a well-considered experimental design is being used to assess the applets' impact on student learning. With respect to broader impacts, the project is using an aggressive dissemination plan featuring conference workshops and mini-courses, a dedicated web server for exploring and downloading the applets, plus the GeoGebraWiki to facilitate interactions among developers and users. The flexibility of the GeoGebra software and its adaptability for use on multiple platforms including mobile devices also contribute to the project's potential for broad impact and support from a growing community of GeoGebra developers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Linear Algebra is an important college mathematics course for many students of engineering, statistics, mathematics, business, economics, and chemistry, for example, find the practical knowledge and techniques valuable to solving problems in their own disciplines. As a powerful mathematical set of interrelated topics, it has a very strong algebraic side, but an equally strong visual geometric side, and the connections between these two perspectives lend the subject a unique ability to contribute problem solving tools to a wide variety of areas of study. Yet, traditional instruction, often focused on symbol manipulation and multistep calculation, has often proved a barrier to success. Rote manipulation of symbols does not foster understanding.  The visual geometric side allows the student to understand the relationships among concepts gaining an understanding of the mathematics. The calculations no longer are mindless but have meaning and are seen as part of the amazing and beautiful relationships between the algebra and visual nature of topics.

The overall goal of this Linear Algebra project is to create interactive tools to help students deepen their understanding of these connections. Careful attention has been given in the design of the linear algebra interactive visualization applets (the programs) to let a student understand the mathematical concepts first, before the mathematics is tied to the mathematical language of vocabulary, symbols, operations, and algebraic manipulation of Linear Algebra. Through interactive visualization, a student directly experiences the meaning of the mathematics of linear algebra by interacting with the relationships among its concepts and their constructs. The approach is not to compartmentalize concepts, but rather blend them together to reveal relationships among them. Along the way, vocabulary, symbols, operations, and algebraic manipulation are introduced after mathematical understanding is achieved.

The applets from this project address topics taught in a first course of linear algebra. Each topic is packaged with a video (showing how the applets works), the applet, and learning activities, for demonstration and interactive student learning. New applets addressing additional topics will continue to be uploaded to the GeoGebra Book Transforming Linear Algebra Education with GeoGebra at  https://www.geogebra.org/m/XnfUWvvp . They are freely available for any Linear Algebra instructor or student to use.  The applets are built on the GeoGebra platform, an open-source, internationally published and managed software program designed for the teaching and learning of mathematics at every level.
